title: Alita font alternatives?
content:
I'm designing a book and would love to use [Alita](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/alita_reg.asp), but alas the family is quite limited. Any suggestions for a (super) close alternative?

I've considered [Amalia](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.ourtype.be/), [Dederon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.suitcasetype.com/index.php?lmut=en&part=fonts&font=9) and [Dolly](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/underware.nl/site2/index.php3?id1=dolly&id2=overview), but they don't quite make up for Alita's unique postmodern qualities. I've also considered [Oxtail](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_oxtail.html) but it's way on the other end of the spectrum.

I understand I might just be stubborn, but thought I'd seek advice. Anything helps, thanks!
author: candice

comments.content:
No apologies. Stubbornness can lead to perfection!

If you can live without the whacky 'g', then maybe [Melior](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/linotype/melior_virtual/) or [Utopia](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018221327/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Utopia) is for you.
